awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: Mixed reality wearable technology to improve workflow, productivity, and training in medical sterilization environments
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to help hospitals improve their sterile processing departments (SPD), where decontamination, sterilization, and assembly of medical equipment and devices occur. The company’s proposed solution seeks to enhance SPD technicians’ work performance and skill levels, decrease SPDs’ operating costs, reduce Hospital Associated Infections (HAI) and Surgical Site Infections (SSI), lessen expensive surgical delays, and reduce related healthcare service delivery costs. Sterile processing technicians play a critical role in preventing infection by sterilizing, cleaning, processing, assembling, storing, and distributing medical supplies. They are directly responsible for disinfection and sterilization of hospital instruments/devices. The team uses mixed reality designed to augment the day-to-day work responsibilities of SPD technicians while supporting the cost-effectiveness of operating a SPD. The solution’s digital content and holograms provide an immersive experience increasing competency, maximizing workflow, and boosting productivity.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project incorporates three applications into augmented reality hardware to enhance the job performance of sterile processing department (SPD) technicians. The applications include barcode/radio frequency identification (RFID) reading, traceability and surgical instrument detection, and inspection utilizing Visual Inertial Odometry (VIO).  These applications are designed to provide efficient and accurate tracking, improved workflow, and increased worker productivity. The research goals of the project include creating a software application programming interface (API) capable of reading barcodes and RFID tags. By providing additional monitoring and tracking capabilities with automated data within the users' field of view and creating an application to enhance object detection capabilities, SPDs in hospitals, doctors' offices and at-home care locations can learn, in real time, the best practices for sterilization of infected surfaces to enable safer and healthier living and work spaces.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
STEAMVision? Phase I NSF grant project made significant progress toward its major goals and objectives during the six-month timeframe. The project achieved the following milestones:

1. SPD Barcode Reader Results: Preliminary results indicate that the headset can read barcodes effectively. However, the user interface requires further refinement to ensure smoother interaction. The ability to read a broad range of SPD-specific barcodes was successfully implemented, with minor formatting adjustments needed for optimal readability.

2. On-Demand Tracking Feature Results: By visiting a urological surgery center in Denver, critical data were collected for location and navigation protocols. This visit significantly facilitated the development of the on-demand tracking feature and live video feed accessory. These features are essential for technicians to efficiently locate items in the sterile processing department.

3. Interactive Inspection and Manipulation Tool Results: The dashboard provides an effective navigation tool, allowing users to manipulate instrument images and zoom for up to 10x magnification. A voice or hand gesture activates a live video feed within the headset field of view, aiding users in locating critical items. The 3-D manipulation and inspection feature demonstrated successful engagement and interactivity during user testing.

4. Education and Training Module Results: Video content, optimized for quick and efficient training, was successfully uploaded to the device. The smooth playback of content ensured a seamless user experience, even with variations in Wi-Fi signal strength. Future goals include making content accessible without an internet connection requirement, ensuring uninterrupted training and education.

Apart from these technical milestones, the project made significant progress in establishing connections with potential investors, incubators, accelerators, and VA hospitals. The principal investigator successfully pitched the STEAMVision? concept, generating interest and invitations for further collaboration and development.

The project did not offer formal opportunities for training and professional development. However, both the principal investigator and senior personnel plan to attend the Healthcare Sterile Processing Association (HSPA) national conference in May 2024 after a successfully attending in May 2023 to continue research and customer discovery efforts.

I product demonstration can be viewed at the project's website (https://www.steamvisionspd.com), providing updates and information for interested parties, as well as opportunities to engage with future activities and continuing results from development.

In summary, STEAMVision? Phase I grant project achieved significant milestones in its development, working toward revolutionizing sterile processing education and training. The project's success in engaging potential investors and establishing valuable connections with the VA and healthcare communities is a testament to its promising future.

The project is poised for its next phase, looking to build upon the foundation laid during Phase I. With strong support and continued development, STEAMVision? aims to enhance healthcare training, improve departmental best practices, and elevate patient safety. The journey is just beginning, with a vision of transforming the healthcare industry while ensuring a strong return on investment.

 


Last Modified: 10/13/2023
Modified by: Scotty Jones
